repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Note: descriptions are AI-generated
# Add `v:argf` to track original startup file arguments [#35847](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35847)

### Problem
- `:args` and `argv()` can change after startup.  
- `v:arg` includes options/commands, not just files.  
- Plugins (e.g. Oil) may rewrite directory args.  

### Solution
- New read-only var `v:argf`: snapshot of file/dir args at startup.  
- Unaffected by `:args` or plugins.  
- Unlike `v:argv`, excludes options/commands.  
- Paths are resolved to absolute paths when possible

### Example
```vim
nvim file1.txt dir1 file2.txt
echo v:argf
" ['/home/user/project/file1.txt', '/home/user/project/dir1', '/home/user/project/file2.txt']
```

fix #35847

comment_data.body: alphanumeric order. this should go before v:argv
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -17,6 +17,16 @@ v:argv
 		list of strings.  The first item is the Vim command.
 		See |v:progpath| for the command with full path.
 
+						*v:argf* *argf-variable*
+v:argf

@@ -265,6 +265,7 @@ static struct vimvar {
   VV(VV_VERSIONLONG,      "versionlong",      VAR_NUMBER, VV_RO),
   VV(VV_ECHOSPACE,        "echospace",        VAR_NUMBER, VV_RO),
   VV(VV_ARGV,             "argv",             VAR_LIST, VV_RO),
+  VV(VV_ARGF,             "argf",             VAR_LIST, VV_RO),

@@ -119,6 +119,7 @@ typedef enum {
   VV_VERSIONLONG,
   VV_ECHOSPACE,
   VV_ARGV,
+  VV_ARGF,

comment_data.body:
We probably should expand the filename to an absolute path, since CWD can change after startup, which would make `v:argf` not very useful thereafter.

And need a test for that scenario.

Also need tests for the `--` case:

    nvim ... -- file1 file2

And need tests that check what happens if the user calls `:argadd` in a `-c` or `--cmd` option:

    nvim --cmd "argadd file1.txt" -c "argadd file2.txt"

This is useful info, but generally the codebase convention is to let the help docs be the source of truth. Since this info repeats `:help v:argf` we don't need to repeat it here. If there were other details that need to be mentioned here then of course this would be the place to do that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1501,6 +1503,38 @@ static void command_line_scan(mparm_T *parmp)
   TIME_MSG("parsing arguments");
 }
 
+/// Initialize v:argf with the startup "file arguments".
+///
+/// This function collects the filenames that were passed on the command line
+/// (and parsed into the global argument list by command_line_scan()) and stores
+/// them in the read-only Vim variable v:argf.
+///
+/// Each filename is expanded to an absolute path at startup, so that v:argf
+/// remains valid even if the current working directory is changed later.
+///
+/// Unlike v:argv, which contains the full argv vector including options
+/// (-u, --cmd, +cmd, etc.), v:argf contains only the raw file arguments
+/// (those appearing after options or after a `--` separator).
+///
+/// Unlike argv(), v:argf is not affected by later :args, :argadd, or plugin
+/// modifications; it is a snapshot of the original file arguments at startup.

comment_data.body:
can avoid the extra allocation by using `vim_FullName` instead of  `FullName_save`, using `NameBuff` as the buf. If it fails that means it was truncated, but that is not something we need to care about here. 4096 is enough for each `v:argf` item.

```suggestion
      (void)vim_FullName(fname, NameBuff, sizeof(NameBuff), false)
      tv_list_append_string(list, NameBuff, -1);
```

```suggestion
  it('stores full path of file args', function()
```

     ]])
   end)
 end)

+  local files = {}
+
+  before_each(function()

+    files = {}
+
+    for _, f in ipairs({
+      'Xargf_file1', 'Xargf_file2',
+      'Xargf_persist',
+      'Xargf_sep1', 'Xargf_sep2'
+    }) do
+      os.remove(f)
+    end
+  end)
+
+  after_each(function()
+    for _, f in ipairs(files) do
+      os.remove(f)
+    end
+  end)
+
+  it('contains absolute paths for startup files', function()

comment_data.body:
also pass a url , `https://example.com`. it should be stored in `v:argf` and `vim_FullName`  will return it unmodified.

do not create a separate test, just add it here as a 3rd arg.

comment_data.body: this is not giving us any coverage, and there is zero risk of "regressing" this, so don't need this test.

+
+  it('contains absolute paths for startup files', function()
+    local file1, file2 = 'Xargf_file1', 'Xargf_file2'
+    write_file(file1, '')
+    write_file(file2, '')

+    local abs1 = fn.fnamemodify(file1, ':p')
+    local abs2 = fn.fnamemodify(file2, ':p')
+
+    local out = fn.system({
+      nvim_prog,
+      '--headless',
+      '-u', 'NONE',
+      '-i', 'NONE',
+      '--cmd', 'echo v:argf',
+      file1,
+      file2,
+      '-c', 'qall',
+    })
+
+    matches(pesc(abs1), out)
+    matches(pesc(abs2), out)
+  end)
+
+  it('retains absolute paths after :cd', function()
+    local file1 = 'Xargf_persist'
+    write_file(file1, '')
+    files = { file1 }
+
+    local abs = fn.fnamemodify(file1, ':p')
+
+    local out = fn.system({
+      nvim_prog,
+      '--headless',
+      '-u', 'NONE',
+      '--cmd', 'cd /',
+      '--cmd', 'echo v:argf',
+      file1,
+      '-c', 'qall',
+    })
+
+    matches(pesc(abs), out)
+  end)
+
+  it('handles -- separator correctly', function()
+    local file1, file2 = 'Xargf_sep1', 'Xargf_sep2'
+    write_file(file1, '')
+    write_file(file2, '')
+    files = { file1, file2 }
+
+    local abs1 = fn.fnamemodify(file1, ':p')
+    local abs2 = fn.fnamemodify(file2, ':p')
+
+    local out = fn.system({
+      nvim_prog,
+      '--headless',
+      '-u', 'NONE',
+      '--cmd', 'echo v:argf',
+      '-c', 'qall',
+      '--',
+      file1,
+      file2,
+    })
+
+    matches(pesc(abs1), out)
+    matches(pesc(abs2), out)
+  end)
+
+  it('is not affected by :argadd in --cmd or -c', function()
+    local out = fn.system({
+      nvim_prog,
+      '--headless',
+      '-u', 'NONE',
+      '--cmd', 'argadd foo.txt',
+      '-c', 'argadd bar.txt',
+      '-c', 'echo len(v:argf)',
+      '-c', 'qall',
+    })
+
+    eq('0', vim.trim(out))
+  end)
+
+  it('is read-only', function()
+    local success, err = pcall(command, "let v:argf = ['foo']")
+    ok(not success)
+    if err then
+      matches('E46', err)
+    else
+      error('Expected E46 error when assigning to v:argf')

comment_data.body: use `n.spawn_wait()` . that avoids needing all the `-u ... -i`, it does that automatically. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/28157738e3de7675a7527f6e4e3fb01e6d30e1bf/test/functional/core/main_spec.lua#L58-L65

comment_regular_data.body:
Looks ok to me, but the verbosity indicates that this was AI generated. Always mention that, and also please prune the irrelevant details where possible. The PR, and its description, should be complete yet concise.

And as the issue label indicates, I would prefer if I heard whether people actually want this feature, or if I missed some other possible way to achieve it already.

Thank u for the feedback!

> And as the issue label indicates, I would prefer if I heard whether people actually want this feature, or if I missed some other possible way to achieve it already.

Yeah, keeping this as a draft
This is close to ready. Please check the results yourself, I feel like I'm reviewing AI results from a distance.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(startup): add v:argf for startup file arguments
